item.title: Phantom Brave: The Lost Hero - Best Early-game Units
item.description:
Phantom Brave: The Lost Hero continues the story of Marona the Chroma and her Spirit Companion Ash. After an encounter with the Shipwreck Fleet, Marona is separated from Ash and washes up on Skullrock Island. After joining forces with a Phantom Pirate, Apricot, Marona sets out to revitalise the Argento Pirate Crew and take on the Shipwreck Fleet to track down Ash.

In order to bolster your forces in Phantom Brave: The Lost Hero , you'll recruit Phantoms with various abilities and skillsets to call forth in combat. Depending on the type of strategies you employ, some units will be more valuable than others. This guide will discuss some of the most universally helpful units available in the early stages of the game.

Best Units in Chapter 1

When you first unlock the "Create Character" Facility in Chapter 1, you'll only have access to a few types of units. Despite this, there are some very useful options in this first bunch that should be prioritized.

Fighter & Striker (Learn Skills Facility, Melee Combat Specialists)

The fighter and Striker both make excellent melee combat units in the game's early stages. The Fighter specializes in swords, with balanced attack and defense but a vulnerability to magic attacks, and a powerful skill that strengthens them when surrounded by foes. The Striker prefers spears and has a greater focus on mobility, with a skill that strengthens their attacks after moving, though they share the Fighter's vulnerability to magic attacks.

It's best to have one of these in the early parts of the game since they can handle most of the enemies you'll come across early on with some careful planning (and some support from Marona and Apricot.) It's also important to recruit at least one of these two at the beginning so you can access the "Learn Skills" Facility, which allows your units to learn new skills as they level up and is essential to getting the most out of your team.

Merchant (Unlocks the Shop, Retrieve useful items from battles)

The Merchant is a vital part of your team, allowing you access to the shop facility to outfit the rest of your units while also retrieving useful items from the battlefield with the "Stock" command. They prefer General Items over traditional weapons, thriving when wielding vases, crates, and barrels against your enemies. They're a fairly versatile unit in combat, and as their level increases, the Shop will become better stocked, so bringing them into battle to earn some exp is vital.

If you find a valuable item in a map, and you aren't sure you'll be able to plunder it, the Merchant can use the "Stock" command to add it to the shop. While only one item can be stocked in this way at a time, and you'll have to spend BOR to get the item from the shop, it's still a great way to guarantee access to a good item.

Healer (Heal Allies in Battle, Revive Allies out of Battle)

The Healer is a Unit you'll want early on, to help you get more mileage out of your units, keep Marona alive, and provide defensive buffs. It's important to protect your Healer, though, since they're quite fragile on their own.

The Healer also gives you access to the "Heal" Facility, which lets you restore defeated units outside of battle. This makes the game a lot more forgiving when you lose a unit, so it's important to have this Facility up and running before taking on any of the more dangerous battles.

Sailor (Long-lasting and easy-to-use unit.)

The Sailor is a fairly mediocre unit in terms of stats and masteries, but has the highest REMOVE stat in the game, giving them the ability to remain active for longer than any other unit during battle. This makes them great when confined to gadgets or as additional support in direct combat, and their ability to draw the attention of enemies makes them good for drawing attention away from other units.

When Reincarnating units they can keep the Sailor abilities that raise the REMOVE stat, so training a unit as a Sailor before reincarnating them into another class will result in units that can stay in combat much longer, so leveling up a few Sailors early will make later stages of the game easier.

Witch & Wizard (Elemental Attacks, AOE)

The Witch and the Wizard are both useful units to have around, with the former focusing on long-range damaging magic while the latter specializes in wider AOE attacks. Since friendly fire is a very real threat in this game, you'll need to be cautious with your use of these two, though their ability to hit enemy elemental weaknesses and bypass physical defenses makes them a vital part of your team.

They rank lower in this list since they don't unlock a facility when recruited and are not as necessary in the earlier parts of the game, where your physically inclined units can handle most threats. However, once enemies with high physical defense start showing up, these two will become essential to success.

Best Units Unlocked in Chapter 2

After completing Chapter 1, several new units become available in the "Create Character" facility, granting access to several new facilities in the process.

Angler (Salvage)

Getting an Angler once they become available can be hugely useful for your inventory. They grant access to the Salvage Facility, which allows you to dispatch a team to gather items. The time taken is determined by a combination of your chosen approach and the Salvage Facility's level, but the overall quality of the items (and the titles attached to them) is determined by the Angler's level.

In battle, the Angler specializes in wielding Beach Items to damage and blowback enemies, while negating Overboard (O.B) damage taken by her allies. With enough time and experience, the Angler can become a strong battle unit.

Chef (Juice Bar)

While the Chef's preferred weapon, the Chef's Knife, is a little tricky to find early on, you should still recruit one as soon as they become available to access the Juice Bar. This facility allows you to give some of your experience from each mission to the Juice Bar, which can then be redistributed to any unit you want. This makes it easier to level up new units, lets you spread experience to units that weren't involved in a given battle, and can eventually be upgraded to generate even more EXP than you'd normally receive from any given encounter.

The Chef restores 20% SP to all allies inside his action area when attacking, making him an excellent support unit. Once he gets a Chef's Knife, his Foraging Ability will boost the attack power of his Dex Skills by 45%, making him a formidable attacker. He later gains increased movement while wielding his preferred weapon, along with a powerful bonus to his SP restoration when an allied Angler is on the map. In short, the Chef is good to level up early, since they'll become incredibly powerful as the game continues and can enable units that spend a lot of SP when attacking to go all out.

Zombie (Strength in Numbers)

Zombies are a unit with a simple strategy: Attack in Greater Numbers. Zombies get buffed when other Zombies are on the field, have excellent HP and DEF stats, and after level 5 they can heal themselves for 15% of their HP whenever they attack. Further emphasizing their utility in the early game, Zombies don't need to hold a weapon to be useful, excelling in unarmed combat. Since they have bad Speed and SP, you'll need to make use of Marona's Confast if you want them to attack early in the turn order, though this drawback doesn't prevent them from soaking up hits and drawing enemy attention.

Ghost (Alternate Spellcaster)

Players seeking a Monster Unit Spellcaster might want to consider the Ghost. Where Witch and Wizard specialized in range and AOE, the Ghost instead performs best at inflicting status effects. While it has lower INT and RES when compared to the other magic users, it has better SPD, REMOVE, and movement range. This allows them to act earlier in the turn order, stick around longer, and reposition more easily than their peers.

item.title: Palworld: All Predator Pal Locations
item.description:
Palworld continues to introduce new expansions whilst the game remains in open beta, with each of these new expansions bringing many new additions for players to explore and make the most of. This includes new islands with new Pal specimens to uncover, new Pal gear and base facilities, new weapons and other items, additional Skills and mechanics, and even new NPCs to locate and interact with.

As part of the Feybreak expansion, a new type of Pal Boss was introduced, named Predator Pals. Predator Pals tend to operate as strong boss encounters for players near endgame content, giving players a new challenge and even the possibility to farm the new Predator Core item. However, Predator Pals do not have a guaranteed spawn rate, meaning locating them can be a somewhat difficult task. For this reason, all approximate Predator Pal locations have been included in the guide below, to help players seek out specific targets or craft their own route for farming Predator Cores in bulk.

All Predator Pal Locations in Palworld

In Palworld , Predator Pals have a chance to randomly spawn at designated locations, though this is not guaranteed. This means that reliably finding Predator Pals, especially in repetition, can be a difficult task. Before seeking out Predator Pals, players will need to ensure they come prepared with plenty of weapons, ammunition, and a strong Pal team to aid them in battle - as well as items to restore health after each battle. Predator Pals can not be caught, but they can drop Predator Cores and Giant Pal Souls, making them targets for farming such items.

Predator Pals will not appear on your map as marked spawn points, meaning players must discover them without the use of the map. Predator Pals can be identified by their glowing red eyes, red aura, and the title 'Rampaging' in their name.

If you're seeking out Predator Pals, a complete list of every approximate spawn point has been included below, complete with map coordinates and any important notes, such as night-exclusive spawns. Players can match these coordinates on their own in-game maps, and place markers to pinpoint locations for easier access.

item.title: 8 Best Soulslike Games That Have Easy Boss Fights
item.description:
Summary

  • Some Soulslike games offer easier bosses for entry-level players, deviating from the usual difficulty.
  • Games like Remnant: From the Ashes provide dynamic difficulty curves to accommodate solo players.
  • Titles like Another Crab's Treasure add vibrancy and versatility, making the Soulslike genre more approachable.

Considering the hard-as-nails difficulty that has become synonymous with the FromSoftware-inspired Soulslike genre, the concept of easy bosses in such a title comes across as a little counter-intuitive. However, with more casual-audience intended titles implementing many of the tropes and mechanics FromSoftware has defined, the creation of more entry-level challenges has been necessary.

From Metroidvania-inspired Soulslikes implementing popular licensed properties to action platformers that incorporate the Soulslike system of level progression and boss style, the expanse of the Soulborne-inspired genre has ensured a lineup of boss fights that are unbecomingly easy to defeat.

8 Remnant: From The Ashes

A Third-Person Shooter Soulslike That Pushes Players To Play On Their Own

Considering that "blasting bosses away" is one of the major draws for Soulslike titles such as Gunfire Games' Remnant: From the Ashes , the genre does tend to put some seemingly immovable obstacles in the player's path. Gunfire Games' title not only begins with choosing a difficulty setting at the beginning of a player's journey working counter to the Soulsborne series' staple in doing so but defaults players to its appropriately named 'Normal' setting. However, with seasoned Soulslike players seemingly finding 'Normal' difficulty too easy, the default setting may be the ideal jumping-off point for new players, yet too forgiving for some.

Considering Remnant: From the Ashes ' cooperative nature, some players may look at playing with friends as a useful crutch for a difficult stretch. However, with a dynamic difficulty curve Gunfire Games ensures that solo players face bosses with lower health and damage output it's emphatically easier to play by yourself.

7 Ashen

The Action-RPG That Implements Co-Op Play & A Cel-Shaded Aesthetic

With a minimalistic cel-shaded art style and a concerted thematic focus on hope and perseverance, 2018's action role-playing title Ashen is a definite step away from the brooding atmosphere of the Soulsborne series.

With AI companions to aid on the journey, the crushing loneliness and resignation that can plague Soulslike titles is somewhat avoided, as even the toughest bosses can be approached with the assistance of a human or computer-controlled comrade. Touted as a "thematically refreshing step forward in the modern line of Dark Souls -likes," Ashen may not be an easy game, but its approaches to Soulslike gameplay staples create a comparatively unchallenging yet engaging experience.

6 Lies Of P

Arlo Collodi's Pinocchio Tale Reborn As A Soulslike With Expansive Combat Options

In an arguably extreme adaptation of the original 1883 story of Pinocchio , Neowiz Games & Round8 Studio's Lies of P brought Arlo Collodi's classic tale to life through the teeth-grinding genre of the Soulslike. The collaboratively developed Soulsborne-esque title was not only a tremendous commercial success, but a cultural success as well, with its Xbox Game Pass debut bringing it and the subscription service much acclaim.

However, despite its clear FromSoftware inspiration, Lies of P while not a walk in the park for most players is seemingly not an incessantly difficult title. With an extravagant set of play mechanics and abilities to choose from, Lies of P puts a great amount of control into the player's hands with the expectation that doing so will allow players to get to terms with the title in their own time. Bolster this with the game's generous placement of save points before boss fights, and players will be able to have a combative dance with the game's most difficult enemies without the Soulsborne series' reviled backtracking.

5 The Last Faith

A 2D Adaptation Of Metroidvania & Soulslike Mechanics That Prioritizes The Former

Despite the proclamation that Playstack's Soulslike Metroidvania is "perhaps the closest thing fans will ever get to a 2D Bloodborne, " arguably a lot of The Last Faith 's difficulty stems from its Metroidvania roots.

Levying stat and equipment leveling against boss and mob characters more than twitch-reflexes and dodging, The Last Faith seemingly encourages exploration over attrition. However, with the attempt to merge Metroidvania and Soulslike genres come some teething pains where the aligned styles of game butt heads, as can occur when boss fights and world observation encourages differing playstyles. However, if players venture into The Last Faith understanding that it avowedly places much of its focus on unearthing the game world rather than constant engagement with difficult bosses, its intentions may well be more clearly received.

4 Mortal Shell

A Dark Souls-Inspired Fantasy Title With Multiple Defensive Options For Players

While Cold Symmetry's 2020 Soulslike Mortal Shell is incredibly open about its FromSoftware inspirations, its mechanics and eponymous gimmicks help to create an experience that is less about breaking through a boss fight-shaped brick wall and more centered on the experience of dueling them.

The game's combat mechanics prove to be Mortal Shell 's entry-level saving grace, as bosses can be intrinsically more difficult to defeat without utilizing them. From the game's 'Harden' ability, allowing players to shrug off a strike's damage before punishing its wind-down animations, to 'Shells' that allow for an added and trait-focused ghostly outer layer, Mortal Shell bestows players with multiple ways to stay defensively viable while remaining on the attack.

3 Demon's Souls (Remake)

The Easiest Set Of Boss Fights Of The Soulsborne Series

Despite 2009's Demon's Souls firing the starting pistol for the Soulsborne series and an entire genre of Soulslike titles many aspects of its design have been tweaked or reimagined in later titles. However, its place in video game history cannot be ignored, and with the 2020 Bluepoint Games-developed remake bringing tighter controls, modern online features, and PlayStation 5 visuals to the property, its legacy is palpable.

Yet, from the game's original release to the PS5-launch title reveal, Demon's Souls' bosses were arguably never nearly as challenging as the game's cramped environments were. From the Demon's Souls remake's reintegration of online features such as co-op play, and seemingly every boss having a particular weak spot, "there's almost always a way to make Demon's Souls boss fights a little easier." However, with tight dungeons filled with enemies and long tracks back to the boss arena if defeated, the world itself can be harder to overcome than any of Demon's Souls' massive mobs.

2 Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order

The Accessibility Of Jedi Combat Ensures An Approachable Soulslike Experience

Coming off of the developer's critically successful Titanfall titles, Respawn Entertainment's Star Wars -themed Soulslike title is not simply a Lucasfilm-inspired action game but an acclaimed entry-level Soulslike experience for those not used to the genre.

Set during the oppressive time period between George Lucas' prequel and original trilogy motion pictures, Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order follows a Jedi Padawan in hiding, Cal Kestis, who embarks on a galaxy-spanning adventure to discover himself and his place in the universe. Although players will be faced with bounty hunters, overgrown fauna, and Sith Inquisitors, Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order 's expansive force and lightsaber customization ensures that no boss fights quite approach the difficulty of the Soulsborne games it draws inspiration from.

1 Another Crab's Treasure

A Child-Friendly Take On The Hardened Genre Of Soulslike Titles

Considering Another Crab's Treasure 's cartoonishly vibrant and jovial appearance, its application of the Soulslike genre is not only creative but approachable. Bolstered by Aggro Crab's development of a robust yet versatile shell armor system and a preoccupation with fluid movement and combat, one of 2024's most notable indie releases simultaneously becomes a particularly welcoming Soulsborne-inspired title.

In playing through Another Crab's Treasure , players will not only navigate the title's tightly wound movement-based platforming sections and chirpy world of undersea characters but also fill an arsenal with varied defensive options for the titular hermit crab to utilize. While many Soulslike titles put an inordinate amount of creative and mechanical energy into ensuring that its boss fights are as nail-bitingly foreboding as possible, Another Crab's Treasure 's focus on engaging yet well-paced bosses ensures that not all of its hardest enemies are genre-definingly difficult.

item.title: Haikyuu Legends Style Tier List
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Haikyuu Legends Style Tier List
  • Best Haikyuu Legends Styles

Haikyuu Legends is an example of a great sports simulator. It is skill-based, and because of this, every match becomes a real challenge, in which you have to use your skills and teamwork. But this does not mean that you can not improve your skills. So, in this Tier List, you can find all Haikyuu Legends Styles from the best to the mediocre. Styles do not give you new abilities in this Roblox game, but they affect how well you can do various actions, such as jumping or spiking.

Haikyuu Legends Style Tier List

As you play matches, you will find your favorite style of play. And at this stage, you should start spinning Styles.

Each of the Styles has a unique set of stats. Some are extremely good in several abilities, while others are average in everything. And of course, as expected from an RNG-based game, all Styles are divided into rarities, of which there are 5 in Haikyuu Legends :

  • Secret - 0.1% Drop rate
  • Godly - 0.49% Drop rate
  • Legendary - 2% Drop rate
  • Rare - 35% Drop rate
  • Common - 62.5% Drop rate

Fortunately, even among Rare and Legendary ones, you can find worthy Styles that will help you play more effectively on the field. Therefore, we have ranked all Haikyuu Legends styles below based on their stats.

Tiers Styles
S Tier Sanu, Oigawa, Bokuto, Uchishima
A Tier Yabu, Kuzee, Azamena, Kosumi, Kagayomo
B Tier Iwaezeni, Yomomute, Sagafura
C Tier Haibo, Tsuzichiwa, Hinoto, Tonoko, Yamegushi, Iwaezeni, Ojiri, Saguwuru, Kito, Nichinoya

Best Haikyuu Legends Styles

Among all the Styles in Haikyuu Legends , a few stand out in particular. So, if you have a lot of Spins, you should try to get the following ones:

  • Sanu - Despite being the rarest Style in the game, it is great for both the Blocker and Spiker roles. So, with it, you can show yourself well no matter where you stand on the field. For this reason, if you have this Style, you should definitely use it.
  • Bokuto - This Style is a bit similar to Sanu, but significantly surpasses it in jumping. For this reason, it is ideal for blocking any enemy attacks.
  • Oigawa - Oigawa will not shine on the field if you play alone since it is suitable for support players. But if played correctly in a team, this Style can change the course of a match, and you will easily win matches.

item.title: Eternal Strands: Best Locations To Farm Steel
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Best Locations To Farm Steel In Eternal Strands
    • Glintwood Hollow
    • Dredger's Mire

Eternal Strands does not feature a skill tree, and that ties all the player's progression to Strands (magical abilities) and their equipment, including weapons and armor pieces. That's the main reason why farming materials to craft new gear or upgrade existing ones is quite important, allowing players to keep up with the increasing difficulty of enemies.

The crafting system in Eternal Strands works a little bit differently from traditional systems, with players being free to craft their gear with different materials from the same category. However, using each material has a different impact on the stats, and the high-value materials give bigger stat boosts. For those looking to use Steel in their upgrades, here are the best spots in Eternal Strands to farm it.

Best Locations To Farm Steel In Eternal Strands

Steel is a 2-star Forged Resource, and while it's by no means a good upgrade for the mid-game or late-game realms, it's a pretty solid starter material for players to use to reforge their existing equipment and increase their stats significantly.

Glintwood Hollow

There are two major locations in Glintwood Hollow that always spawn Steel/Bronze ores. As highlighted by a red line on the map above, these ores spawn on top of narrow ledges . There are always three rocks along each line shown on the map.

Dredger's Mire

This realm is more dangerous than Glintwood Hollow for farming Steel, but if you still plan to visit the place anyway, it's worth paying a visit to the west side of The Akron's Expanse. There is a big cliff here, on the foot of which there are a few Steel/Bronze ores.

With the original gear, players can only damage Steel/Bronze ore using a charged melee attack. The normal melee attack will deal no damage, and a bow attack will deal very minimal damage.

Earlier in the game, Steel will be one of the best Forged Materials that players can use to upgrade weapons and armor pieces, offering +12 damage over the original Sword and Shield. Being a neutral ore, Steel doesn't have any positive or negative impact on Cold or Heat resistance.

The other higher-level realms in Eternal Strands still drop Steel through chests and other sources, but it's usually harder to find Steel ores, as they are mainly replaced with Serenite/Candescite ores. Candescite is a 3-star Forged Material and grants better stat boosts compared to Steel.

That being said, this doesn't mean that Steel will be useless near the end of the game. Knowing that each Steel ore can be exchanged for two Camp Supplies, players can still farm it to acquire said supplies and then upgrade the workshops at the camp. The Camp Supplies required for upgrading will significantly increase from Level 3 onward, so even if you don't have a use case for Steel ores anymore, it is recommended to save them in the camp for upcoming upgrades.
